Statistical information under null and alternative hypothesis

Source: vignettes/articles/story-info-formula.Rmd
story-info-formula.Rmd

In a group sequential design of the kk-th analysis, the Z-score is Zk=δk/Var(δk|H0) Z_k = \delta_k / \sqrt{\text{Var}(\delta_k | H_0)} The statistical information ℐk\mathcal I_k is defined as the inverse of the variance of δk\delta_k, i.e., ℐk=1/Var(δk). \mathcal I_k = 1 / \text{Var}(\delta_k).

Continuous outcomes

Imagine a trial with a continuous outcome. Let X0,i∼N(μ0,σ2)X_{0, i} \sim N(\mu_0, \sigma^2) for subjects i=1,…,n0i = 1, \ldots, n_0 in the control arm and X1,i∼N(μ1,σ2)X_{1,i} \sim N(\mu_1, \sigma^2) for patient ii (i=1,…,n1i = 1, \ldots, n_1) in the experimental arm.

For a superiority design, the tested hypothesis is H0:μ0=μ1vs.H1:μ1>μ0. H_0: \; \mu_0 = \mu_1 \;\;\; \text{vs.} \;\;\; H_1:\; \mu_1 > \mu_0. Suppose at the kk-th analysis, there are n0kn_{0k} subjects in the control arm, and there are n1kn_{1k} subjects in the experimental arm. We have δk\delta_k as the difference of group means, i.e., δk=∑i=1n1kXi,1n1k−∑i=1n0kXi,0n0k. \delta_k = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{1k}} X_{i,1}}{n_{1k}} - \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{0k}} X_{i,0}}{n_{0k}}. It can be estimated as δ̂k=∑i=1n1kxi,1n1k−∑i=1n0kxi,0n0k\widehat\delta_k = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{1k}} x_{i,1}}{n_{1k}} - \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{0k}} x_{i,0}}{n_{0k}}, where xi,jx_{i,j} are the observation of Xi,jX_{i,j} of subject ii in arm jj.

The statistical information ℐk\mathcal I_k is ℐk−1=Var(δk|H0)=σ2(1/n1k+1/n0k), \mathcal I_k^{-1} = \text{Var}(\delta_k | H_0) = \sigma^2 (1 / n_{1k} + 1 / n_{0k}), under both H0H_0 and H1H_1, which can be estimated as ℐk=σ̂2(1/n1k+1/n0k)\mathcal I_k = \widehat\sigma^2 (1 / n_{1k} + 1 / n_{0k}).

Binary outcomes

Imagine a trial with a binary outcome. Let X0,i∼B(p0)X_{0, i} \sim B(p_0) for patient i=1,…,n0i = 1, \ldots, n_0 and X1,i∼B(p1)X_{1,i} \sim B(p_1) for patient ii (i=1,…,n1i = 1, \ldots, n_1), where p0p_0 and p1p_1 are failure rate probability. Suppose at the kk-th analysis, there are n0kn_{0k} subjects in the control arm, and there are n1kn_{1k} subjects in the experimental arm. For a superiority design, the null and alternative hypothesis is H0:p0=p1=pvs.H1:p0>p1. H_0: \; p_0 = p_1 = p \;\;\; \text{vs.} \;\;\; H_1:\; p_0 > p_1. The nature-scale treatment effect is δk=∑i=1n1kXi,1n1k−∑i=1n0kXi,0n0k, \delta_k = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{1k}} X_{i,1}}{n_{1k}} - \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{0k}} X_{i,0}}{n_{0k}}, It can be estimated as δ̂k=∑i=1n1kxi,1n1k−∑i=1n0kxi,0n0k\widehat\delta_k = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{1k}} x_{i,1}}{n_{1k}} - \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{0k}} x_{i,0}}{n_{0k}}, where xi,jx_{i,j} are the observation of Xi,jX_{i,j} of subject ii in arm jj.

The statistical information is ℐk−1=Var(δk)={p(1−p)/n1k+p(1−p)/n0kunder H0p1(1−p1)/n1k+p0(1−p0)/n0kunder H1. \mathcal I_k^{-1} = \text{Var}(\delta_k) = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} p(1-p)/n_{1k} + p(1-p)/n_{0k} & \text{under } H_0\\ p_1(1-p_1)/n_{1k} + p_0(1-p_0)/n_{0k} & \text{under } H_1\\ \end{array} \right.. Its estimation is ℐ̂k−1={p‾(1−p‾)/n1k+p‾(1−p‾)/n0kunder H0p̂1(1−p1)/n1k+p̂0(1−p̂0)/n0kunder H1, \widehat{\mathcal I}_k^{-1} = \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \bar p(1 - \bar p) / n_{1k} + \bar p(1 - \bar p) / n_{0k} & \text{under } H_0\\ \widehat p_1(1-p_1) / n_{1k} + \widehat p_0(1 - \widehat p_0)/n_{0k} & \text{under } H_1\\ \end{array} \right., where p‾=∑i=1n1kxi1+∑i=1n0kxi0n1k+n0k\bar p = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{1k}}x_{i1} + \sum_{i=1}^{n_{0k}}x_{i0}}{n_{1k} + n_{0k}}, p̂j=∑i=1njkxijnjk\widehat p_j = \frac{\sum_{i=1}^{n_{jk}}x_{ij}}{n_{jk}} for j=0,1j = 0, 1.

Survival outcome

In many clinical trials, the outcome is the time to some event. For simplicity, assume the event is death so that each person can only have one event; the same ideas apply for events that can recur, but in those cases we restrict attention to the first event for each patients. We use the logrank statistics to compare the treatment and control arms. If we assume there are NkN_k total number of deaths at analysis kk. The numerator of the logrank statistics at analysis kk is (Proschan, Lan, and Wittes 2006) ∑i=1NkDi, \sum_{i=1}^{N_k} D_i, where Di=Oi−EiD_i = O_i - E_i with OiO_i is the indicator that the iith death occurred in a treatment patient, and Ei=m1i/(m0i+m1i)E_i = m_{1i} / (m_{0i} + m_{1i}) as the null expectation of OiO_i given the respective numbers, m0im_{0i} and m1im_{1i}, of control and treatment patients at risk just prior to the iith death.

Conditioned on m0im_{0i} and m1im_{1i}, the OiO_i has a Bernoulli distribution with parameter EiE_i. The null conditional mean and variance of DiD_i are 0 and Vi=Ei(1−Ei)V_i = E_i(1 − E_i), respectively.

Unconditionally, the DiD_i are uncorrelated, mean 0 random variables with variance E(Vi)E(V_i) under the null hypothesis.

Thus, conditioned on NkN_k, we have ℐk−1=Var(δk)=∑i=1NkVar(Di)=∑i=1NkE(Vi)=E(∑i=1NkVi)=E(∑i=1NkEi(1−Ei))={E(∑i=1Nkr1+r11+r)under H0E(∑i=1Nkm1i(m0i+m1i)m0i(m0i+m1i))under H1, \begin{array}{ccl} \mathcal I_k^{-1} & = & \text{Var}(\delta_k) = \sum_{i=1}^{N_k} \text{Var}(D_i) = \sum_{i=1}^{N_k} E(V_i) = E \left( \sum_{i=1}^{N_k} V_i \right) = E \left( \sum_{i=1}^{N_k} E_i(1 − E_i) \right) \\ & = & \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} E\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N_k} \frac{r}{1+r} \frac{1}{1+r} \right) & \text{under } H_0\\ E\left(\sum_{i=1}^{N_k} \frac{m_{1i}}{(m_{0i} + m_{1i})} \frac{m_{0i}}{(m_{0i} + m_{1i})}\right) & \text{under } H_1 \end{array} \right., \end{array} where rr is the randomization ratio. Its estimation is ℐ̂k−1={∑i=1Nkr1+r11+runder H0∑i=1Nkm1i(m0i+m1i)m0i(m0i+m1i)under H1. \begin{array}{ccl} \widehat{\mathcal I}_k^{-1} & = & \left\{ \begin{array}{ll} \sum_{i=1}^{N_k} \frac{r}{1+r} \frac{1}{1+r} & \text{under } H_0\\ \sum_{i=1}^{N_k} \frac{m_{1i}}{(m_{0i} + m_{1i})} \frac{m_{0i}}{(m_{0i} + m_{1i})} & \text{under } H_1 \end{array} \right.. \end{array}

References

Proschan, Michael A., K. K. Gordon Lan, and Janet Turk Wittes. 2006. Statistical Monitoring of Clinical Trials: A Unified Approach. New York, NY: Springer.
